There's no one to turn to.
There is no hope.
This is your life now.

>>245200205
>Few manga I've come accross have the same kind of feeling of fantasy and wonder as it does. I think it's unpopular because for a full effect you should know at least a bit of Japanese myths and legends
Completely agreed, though I'll add it also helps if you have some science/philosophy background too. And heck, other areas of myth as well. It does surprisingly interesting combinations of Japanese mythology with fairly cutting edge physics and such, and it avoids WORDSWORDSWORDS dumbing stuff down. While it should be enjoyable for anyone who likes the genre, there are a lot of layers that make it special. Don't know if the author can keep it up all the way through for a strong finale but what there is is just incredibly unique.
>Overhyping anything can lead something to feel flat even though it's good, it took me a few chapters and a couple of re-reads of them to fully appreciate it, but it is genuinely terrific
This too. Always a risk with sharing something, I try to be realistic about it, and sometimes the most amazing experiences are going in fairly unspoiled or discovering it by complete surprise but of course that's pretty hit and miss. It is too bad how if something does get more attention sometimes it ends up provoking contrarianism too.

But Touge is just really solid. I don't want to go too far for ANY manga still running because we've all seen brilliant beginnings and midways get squandered in the end a bunch of times, but with that caveat it's still well worth a shot.

Funny from start to finish and almost everyone gets a cool moment. And how the whole Curse motif impacted the manga twice with <s>Risu</s> and <s>The Hole</s> was really well done and unexpected. Whole manga feels random at first, but 90% of the powers and plot twist feel like they were planned from chapter 1. Ridiculous in a positive way. Don't think there is a single characte I hated either.
